Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to head out the door to vote. It was Jamie, my closest friend, sending a string of messages about how drained and lonely she felt after a long, uneventful day at work. I could almost hear her sighs through the screen, and I knew she needed someone to listen, to remind her she mattered. That’s what friends do—we show up, even if it’s just through a phone call or a few thoughtful replies.

But the clock was ticking. The polling station was open all day, and I’d promised myself I’d vote before dinner. It wasn’t urgent, but I felt a responsibility to participate, to make my voice heard. I kept glancing at the time, torn between the duty I owed my community and the comfort I owed my friend. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, unsure whether to call Jamie and risk running late, or to send a quick reply and head out, hoping she’d understand. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
